document.docTitle: Prunus yunkaishanensis B. H. Wu, W. Y. Zhao & W. B. Liao OL 2022, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Prunus yunkaishanensis (Rosaceae), a new species from Guangdong, South China

paragraph.heading:
Prunus yunkaishanensis B.H. Wu, W.Y. Zhao & W.B. Liao
,
sp. nov.
( Figures 2 & 3 (G–I)).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Prunus yunkaishanensis
. A. Habitat. B. Habit. C. Portion of stem, showing its reddish-brown bark with small lenticels. D. Leaves, adaxial view. E. Stipules. F. Leaf nectaries at the base of leaf abaxial surface. G. Part of leaf abaxial surface, showing sparse punctation. H. Flower, showing reflexed petals that are shorter than stamens. I. Raceme, showing stout rachis and bracts persistent during anthesis. J. Flowering branch, showing racemes in axils of extant or fallen leaves. K. Bract, adaxial view. L. Endocarp, showing reticulately rugose surface. M. Fruiting branch with ovoid fruits.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis: —
Prunus yunkaishanensis
is morphologically similar to
P . phaeosticta
and
P. fordiana
, but differs from the latter two species by its larger leaves with more pairs of lateral veins, shorter inflorescences with stout rachises, bracts persistent during anthesis and ovoid fruits.

Type:—
CHINA . Guangdong : Gaozhou , Magui Town , Daxi Village , Qiecaiping ( Yunkai Shan area ), in valley, 22°14'59.85" N , 111°16’5.23” E ,
700 m a.s.l.
,
1 November 2020
(fl.),
B.H . Wu
& W.Y. Zhao P20201562 ( Holotype IBSC!; Isotypes IBSC!, SYS!)
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Morphological comparison of
Prunus phaeosticta
,
P . fordiana
and
P . yunkaishanensis
.
P. phaeosticta
( A–C ): A. Leaf blade with cuneate base; B. Inflorescence with slender rachis and soon caducous bracts; C. Infructescence with subglobose fruits.
P . fordiana
( D–F ): D. Leaf blade with cuneate base; E. Inflorescence with slender rachis and soon caducous bracts; F. Infructescence with an ellipsoid fruit.
P. yunkaishanensis
( G–I ): G. Leaf blade with rounded or slightly cordate base; H. Inflorescence with stout rachis and bracts persistent during anthesis; I. Infructescence with ovoid fruits. A, C from X.X. Huang et al. 18800 (IBSC 0860099); B from S. P. Ko 54147 (IBSC 0338000); D from Department of Forestry 90687 (IBSC 0315466); E from F.C. How 71653 (IBSC 0315481); F from N. Liu et al. 2662 (IBSC 0315463); G from B.H. Wu & W.Y. Zhao P20201562 (IBSC); H from B.H. Wu & W.Y. Zhao P20201558 (IBSC); I from B.H. Wu & X.Q. Wen P20201635 (IBSC).

subSubSection.paragraph: Description:— Small trees, 3–4 m tall. Bark reddish brown, with small lenticels. Branchlets reddish-brown, glabrous, with sparsely small lenticels. Winter buds ovoid. Stipules lanceolate, 0.3–0.5 cm long. Petioles glabrous, (0.2–)0.35–0.55(–0.8) cm long; leaf blades thinly coriaceous, oblong-oblanceolate to oblanceolate, rarely narrowly elliptic, 14–20 × 4.5–6.0 cm, base rounded, rarely slightly cordate or broadly cuneate, apex caudate, rarely acuminate or cuspidate, margin undulate or not, sparsely serrate with shallow acicular teeth or only serrate in upper half, rarely wholly entire, both surfaces glabrous, adaxially dark green, abaxially pale green, scatteredly punctate, with 1–2 nectaries at the leaf base (sometimes absence); lateral veins 13–18 pairs, adaxially impressed, abaxially prominent. Racemes solitary, in axils of extant or fallen leaves, 1–3.3 cm long, (1–)3–12 flowered, rachis stout, ca. 1.5 mm in diam., villous; involucre broadly ovate, 3–4 × 3–4 mm , glabrous, margin ciliate; bracts 3–4 × 2–3 mm , broadly ovate, glabrous, margin ciliate, persistent during anthesis; pedicel 1–3(–4) mm, villous; hypanthium shortly campanulate, 1.5–3 × 2.5–4 mm , outside villous, inside glabrous; sepals rounded-triangular, 1.0– 1.8 mm , outside villous, inside glabrous, margin ciliate; petals white, suborbicular, 1.5–2.0 mm long, glabrous, reflexed in blooming flowers; stamens ca. 20; filaments glabrous, 3–4 mm long, base adnate to calyx tube; anthers ca. 0.4 mm long; ovary glabrous, style 4–5 mm long, slightly longer or as long as stamens. Drupe ovoid, 1.5–1.8 × 0.75–0.90 cm , glabrous; endocarp prominently reticulately rugose.

Distribution and habitat :—
Prunus yunkaishanensis
is currently only known from Yunkaishan National Nature Reserve, western Guangdong , and only 10 individuals were discovered. It grows in the moist valley and forest margin at elevations of
650 to 800 m
.
Phenology :—Flowering from October to November, fruiting from December to February (the ensuing year).

Etymology :—The specific epithet refers to the type locality, Yunkai Shan National Nature Reserve in Guangdong Province , China . The Chinese name of the new species is here given as 云开山桂ē (yún kāi shān guì yīng).

Additional specimens examined :—
